channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: The COP30 and COP31 summits must be a display of southern hemisphere stewardship
item.description: Brazil hosts but Australia must prove its climate credentials – leadership is earned through action, not hosting rights.

item.title: Anwar’s international success sours at home
item.description: Malaysia won the world over as host of the ASEAN summit, but domestic politics tells a different story.

item.title: A wall rebuilt in Europe – this one for drones
item.description: Russia’s threats spurred plans for continental air defence, but squabbles over control and capability threaten the project.

item.title: Why Congress Is So Mad at the Pentagon
item.description: Lawmakers—including Republicans—are frustrated over a lack of communication.

item.title: Trump Seeks to Counter Russia, China in Their Own Backyard
item.description: Signing rare-earth deals with Central Asian nations would bolster U.S. influence in the mineral-rich region.

item.title: Trump Hosts Central Asian Nations to Ink Critical Minerals Deals
item.description: Signing rare-earth deals with Central Asian nations would bolster U.S. influence in the mineral-rich region.

item.title: What Went Wrong in Tanzania?
item.description: How the “island of stability” in a turbulent region descended into chaos—and where it goes from here.

item.title: America’s plans for a Golden Dome are dangerously obscure
item.description: Without clarity, the missile shield risks becoming a costly, destabilising white elephant

item.title: America’s Future Is Being Sacrificed for Short-Term “Wins”
item.description: Despite a tumultuous year, markets continue to bet on American liquidity and growth. But while the outlook looks promising, the United States is systematically trading strategic advantages for tactical gains, and the costs are accumulating in ways that won’t become apparent until it’s too late.

item.title: Hezbollah Is Down But Not Out
item.description: Undermining the group in Lebanon requires targeting its networks abroad.

item.title: Agriculture for Security
item.description: One of the main factors contributing to food insecurity is conflict. Policymakers must start viewing agriculture as a strategic sector that not only sustains households, but also anchors fragile states, gives legitimacy to governments, and creates an opening for cooperation in an increasingly fragmented world.

item.title: Africa’s Financial Sovereignty Is Under Attack
item.description: Critics and credit-rating agencies have been challenging the legitimacy of Afreximbank’s preferred creditor status. By casting doubt on the reliability of African institutions, they are threatening to undermine the continent's ability to build a sovereign financial architecture capable of supporting its structural transformation.

item.title: Australia-Japan ties are about shaping outcomes, not hedging bets
item.description: With strong security ties, both countries can influence Washington’s strategy and constrain Beijing’s options.

item.title: How China Spreads Authoritarian Practices Beyond Its Borders
item.description: China encourages autocratic practices in different ways that are tailored to local conditions. Kyrgyzstan and Kazakhstan are prime examples.

item.title: AI Wants Our Water
item.description: While much of the AI debate focuses on its economic potential, its expanding physical footprint tells a different story. The machines driving this revolution depend on a resource far older – and far more contested – than data or electricity.

item.title: Japanese Markets Look Poised to Prosper With New Government, China-US Trade Truce
item.description: With Takaichi's government investing more in emerging tech, private equity markets could see further increases.

item.title: AI Agents Threaten Free Societies
item.description: Accountability for one’s actions is a bedrock principle of any society built on the rule of law. Yet while we understand human autonomy and the responsibilities that come with it, the workings of machine autonomy lie beyond our comprehension, making AI agents an obvious risk to democratic governance.

item.title: Behind the Marble Walls: A Glimpse Into Turkmenistan
item.description: A rare trip to one of the world’s most secretive and authoritarian states.

item.title: The Future of Japan’s Official Development Assistance Under Takaichi
item.description: Takaichi is recasting Japan’s relationship with ASEAN from one of development partnership to one of security cooperation.

item.title: Hong Kongers support gay marriage. Their leaders, not so much
item.description: The city has rejected reform even as other places in Asia embrace it

item.title: What a leaked transcript reveals about China’s muscular statecraft
item.description: It is determined to protect pipelines and rare-earth mines in Myanmar

item.title: The weekly cartoon
Business
Politics
China’s life-sciences industry is turning American
item.description: Meanwhile, America is abandoning its winning formula

item.title: America’s furniture-makers exemplify the folly of tariffs
item.description: Donald Trump is pushing up costs to rescue an industry that has already adapted to globalisation

item.title: Should facial analysis help determine whom companies hire?
item.description: A new paper suggests a photo can tell a recruiter much about an applicant’s personality

item.title: Nigel Farage’s newfound fiscal prudence is welcome, if unproven
item.description: Britain’s leading populist says he won’t cut taxes dramatically after all

item.title: The death of Thailand’s queen mother reveals changing attitudes to the monarchy
item.description: Her mercurial son, as king, does not help

item.title: Indonesia raids its rainy-day pot
item.description: And foreign investors head for the airport

item.title: America and China circle each other in the South China Sea
item.description: Naval tensions around Scarborough shoal are at their highest in years

item.title: America’s health-care costs are shooting up
item.description: One big reason is that people are seeking more treatment

item.title: The rise and fall of America’s model mobile crisis service
item.description: What went wrong with a scheme started by hippies and praised by Zohran Mamdani

item.title: Pope Leo XIV is infuriating MAGA Catholics
item.description: Concern for the poor and the planet rubs some the wrong way

item.title: Why moderates are reclaiming Europe’s national flags
item.description: Populists and nativists have usurped them

item.title: Ukraine’s valiant defence of Pokrovsk is nearing its end
item.description: Russia suffers huge casualties, but its new drone-powered assault is working

item.title: A Czech shift to the right is worrying news for Ukraine
item.description: But the new prime minister will probably not join Viktor Orban’s efforts to block aid

item.title: Iraq’s election may ensure stability but leave militias in control
item.description: This may come at the cost of weakening civil society and wider freedoms

item.title: Donald Trump says he may strike Nigeria to save Christians. Really?
item.description: The reality behind the American president’s latest threats

item.title: Tanzania has its Tiananmen moment
item.description: A post-election crackdown that killed hundreds has changed the country forever

item.title: Will anything—or anyone—stop the slaughter in Sudan?
item.description: As a killing spree unfolds in Darfur, an end to the civil war looks remote

item.title: War looms in Venezuela as Trump tests an “Americas First” doctrine
item.description: A gathering armada risks repeating the mistakes of the “war on terror”

item.title: Queen Sirikit’s death shows changing Thai views of the monarchy
item.description: Her mercurial son, as king, does not help

item.title: Takaichi Government Moves to Expand Japan’s Defense Exports After Komeito’s Exit
item.description: With a willing partner in Nippon Ishin, the ruling LDP is advancing its defense export ambitions.

item.title: 27th Amendment to Pakistan’s Constitution on the Anvil
item.description: The amendment is likely to pass as the ruling coalition has the necessary two-thirds majority in both houses of Parliament.

item.title: China’s Exit Bans Are Breaking a Decades-Long Social Contract
item.description: The widening use of exit bans marks a decisive shift in China’s governance model under Xi Jinping.

item.title: Migration From Kashmir: Between Hope and Heartache
item.description: What unites those who leave the valley in search of jobs isn’t merely departure, it’s disillusionment.

item.title: India’s women win the cricket World Cup
item.description: Their victory is a welcome boost for women’s sport—and for Indian women in general

item.title: South Asia’s water wars
item.description: Climate change and rising energy demand could worsen conflict over rivers

item.title: The Desperate Search for Gaza Peacekeepers
item.description: Most of the world seems very eager to avoid joining the territory’s international stabilization force.

item.title: What explains India’s peculiar stability?
item.description: In a tricky neighbourhood the country remains calm

item.title: America should not push other countries to adopt the dollar
item.description: More dollarisation would be a double-edged sword

item.title: Don’t blame AI for your job woes
item.description: The white-collar chill has more to do with the economy than with tech

item.title: A night of big wins for the Democrats
item.description: Having Donald Trump in the White House but not on the ballot is ideal for the party

item.title: China’s clean-energy revolution will reshape markets and politics
item.description: The world’s biggest manufacturer now has an interest in the world decarbonising

item.title: The rise of singlehood is reshaping the world
item.description: In good ways and bad

item.title: A new industry of AI companions is emerging
item.description: It may have profound implications for society and what it means to be human

item.title: All over the rich world, fewer people are hooking up and shacking up
item.description: Social media, dating apps and political polarisation all play a part

item.title: The Three Technologies Disrupting the Global Order
item.description: The great Austrian economist Joseph Schumpeter argued that you could spot a fundamental economic transition by the arrival of new types of goods, new production methods, and new forms of industrial organization. The spread of cheap drones, phones, and solar checks all of these boxes.

item.title: Renewables, Sustainable Growth and Competition in the East Asian Market
item.description: The proliferation of battery and other renewables technology firms is no guarantee of sustainability, just as profitability today does not promise innovation tomorrow.

item.title: Toppling Maduro Without Boots on the Ground
item.description: Trump would be right to try something new against the Venezuelan regime.

item.title: Madagascar’s ‘Coupvolution’ Is Following a Familiar Pattern
item.description: Gen Z protesters now have buyer's remorse.

item.title: Terror Returns to Darfur
item.description: Only American pressure can stop the killing in Sudan.

item.title: How War in Taiwan Ends
item.description: Even if deterrence fails, America could thwart China.

item.title: Blue Porcelain and Rare Earths
item.description: China’s mineral-rich clays are the raw material for world-renowned porcelain – and super-strong magnets.

item.title: Turning Off Starlink Coverage Won’t Destroy Myanmar’s Scam Centers
item.description: Cutting off the service could impact millions of civilians, while doing little to undermine the country's criminal syndicates.

item.title: Will a trade deal repair India-US ties?
item.description: New Delhi’s optimism about Trump's return has given way to punitive tariffs, stalled negotiations, and diplomatic drift.
